item.title: Afghanistan: British nationals killed in Kabul airport attack
item.description: Two British nationals and the child of another are among the victims of Thursday's attack, the government says.

item.title: Afghanistan: Hundreds left behind as UK ending Kabul evacuation
item.description: With no more people called to the airport, the UK expresses deep regret that some won't be able to leave.

item.title: Afghanistan: Getting plane out was 'happiest moment of my life'
item.description: Former Afghan interpreter Burhan and his family are now in the UK, after begging for help to escape.

item.title: Cristiano Ronaldo: Man Utd 'reach agreement' to re-sign Juventus forward
item.description: Manchester United have confirmed they have reached an agreement to re-sign Cristiano Ronaldo from Juventus.

item.title: Scotland records huge increase in daily Covid cases
item.description: A total of 6,835 new cases were reported on Friday - more than 1,800 above the previous highest figure.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Kadeena Cox sets new world record to win gold
item.description: British star Kadeena Cox sets a new world record to retain her C4-5 500m time trial title at the Tokyo Paralympics.

item.title: Evacuations amid 'explosions' at Leamington Spa fire
item.description: Police at the industrial blaze say one person is unaccounted for as emergency crews work to locate them.

item.title: Convicted gang member bragged about wealth in music videos
item.description: Akeem Chand, 27, rapped about the money he was making through illicit activities.

item.title: Farms face an oversupply of pigs due to staff shortage
item.description: The UK's farmers are warning of a backlog of as many as 70,000 pigs that should have been slaughtered.

item.title: Fulham solicitor accused of injecting blood into stores' food
item.description: The solicitor appeared in court accused of injecting blood into food at three west London stores.

item.title: Bury pub landlord catches Lee Rigby collection box thief
item.description: Stewart Spensley, who served with Lee Rigby, chased the thief when the box was taken from his bar.

item.title: Twelve-year-old boy makes £290,000 from whale NFTs
item.description: Benyamin Ahmed created a set of more than 3,000 whale images and sold digital tokens of them.

item.title: The UK's first all-black, all-female theatre company is shaking up Shakespeare
item.description: Mawa Theatre Company is a UK first and aims to make Shakespeare's work more accessible.

item.title: Man rides scooter home on Aston Expressway after night out
item.description: An intoxicated man decided to ride his scooter along the Aston Expressway after a night out.

item.title: Kanye West: Kim Kardashian attends Donda event in wedding gown
item.description: It was one of several publicity stunts at the rapper's latest "listening party" for his new album.

item.title: Daniel Dias: History's greatest para-swimmer
item.description: Daniel Dias has won more than 25 medals for Brazil over the past four Paralympic Games but will be retiring after Tokyo.

item.title: Autism and anxiety: One man 'failed by the system'
item.description: Autistic teen posted a video about lack of support in health and social care system before he died.

item.title: Springbank whisky miniature sells for £5,600 at auction
item.description: The 5cl Springbank single malt was part of a collection of more than 400 bottles put up for sale.

item.title: Morecambe and Wise 'bored stiff' by Monty Python
item.description: The comedy double act shared their thoughts in an unearthed 1973 interview for a student TV station.

item.title: The Papers: 'Bloodbath at Kabul airport'
item.description: Reports of the twin bomb attacks in Afghanistan's capital feature across the front pages, alongside some dramatic photographs.

item.title: Climate Basics: Can carbon offsetting help the planet?
item.description: BBC Reality Check looks at whether it's possible to buy your way out of creating harmful greenhouse gas emissions.

item.title: Africa's week in pictures: 20-26 August 2021
item.description: A selection of the best photos from the African continent and beyond.

item.title: Eating disorders: Charity reports rise in calls about binge eating
item.description: The charity Beat reports a surge in the number of people requesting help for Binge Eating Disorder.

item.title: Taylor Wessing Prize 2021: Shortlisted photographers revealed
item.description: The three shortlisted photographers for the prestigious Taylor Wessing Prize have been revealed.

item.title: Nah he tweakin: What it means and why it's all over our timelines
item.description: A row on the use of blood in celebrity-endorsed products has made those three words viral.

item.title: Festival fans 'face danger of strong drugs with low tolerance'
item.description: Disruptions could mean people inadvertently take stronger or more dangerous drugs, campaigners say.

item.title: Why is there a chip shortage?
item.description: The big chip crunch is really biting now, leaving even the most unexpected industries in crisis.

item.title: 'Now other women won't be haunted by the labour ward'
item.description: A woman who delivered her stillborn baby in a room next to expectant mothers helps make sure others do not have to.

item.title: Afghanistan's Uyghurs fear the Taliban, and now China too
item.description: Members of the ethnic group say they fear the Taliban takeover could bring China to their doorstep.

item.title: Indian-American gay couples find new forms of union amid stigma
item.description: Although gay marriage is legal in the US, Indian-American couples struggle to find priests to marry them.

item.title: What are the holiday rules for travel to green, amber and red list countries?
item.description: A traffic light system is in place setting out rules for entering the UK

item.title: Ryan Tedder: Classic songs are strangling new music
item.description: New bands don't have a chance because everyone is streaming Queen and ABBA, says the OneRepublic star.

item.title: UK reports 38,281 new cases on Thursday
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: 'My husband refused a divorce for nine years'
item.description: Under orthodox Jewish law, a husband must give his wife a document to allow the marriage to end.

item.title: The real victims of mass crypto-hacks that keep happening
item.description: Millions in Bitcoin and other digital coins are being stolen by hackers with victims left in limbo.

item.title: Verstappen tops Belgium second practice despite crash
item.description: Red Bull's Max Verstappen ends Friday practice at the Belgian Grand Prix with a crash after setting the fastest time ahead of both Mercedes drivers.

item.title: Leicester to play Napoli in Europa League - full draw details
item.description: Leicester, West Ham, Rangers and Celtic discover who they will face in the 2021-22 Europa League group stage, while Tottenham find out their Europa Conference League opponents

item.title: 'To see how much plastic is on the beach was shocking'
item.description: Jamie Chadwick on why even the most dedicated sportspeople need a Sunday roast once in a while...

item.title: England v India: Joe Root too late to send a review as replays show Rohit was out
item.description: Joe Root takes too long to review an lbw against Rohit Sharma, before replays show the batsman would have been out, as England face India on day three of the third Test at Headingley.

item.title: Football Focus: Man Utd's Raphael Varane attracts trophies, says Paul Pogba
item.description: Manchester United's Paul Pogba says his France team-mate Raphael Varane, who has joined this summer from Real Madrid, is a top player who "attracts trophies".

item.title: Kabul airport bomb attacks leave many casualties
item.description: Reports say at least 90 people were killed, with civilians and US military personnel among the dead.

item.title: 'Overwhelming' help given for Afghan refugees in UK
item.description: "No-one chooses to be a refugee, if any of us were in that position I hope we would get support."

item.title: Afghanistan airport attack: Who are IS-K?
item.description: The jihadist group - set up in 2015 - is blamed for some of the worst atrocities in recent years.

item.title: Kabul airport attack: What do we know?
item.description: The bombing came hours after warnings to citizens to stay away from the airport, due to an imminent threat.

item.title: Kabul airport attack: 'I saw doomsday'
item.description: Afghans caught up in the twin blasts outside Kabul airport speak of the horror they witnessed.

item.title: Young Afghan mayor who fled Taliban hidden in car
item.description: One of Afghanistan's first female mayors, Zarifa Ghafari, describes her dramatic escape to Germany.

item.title: Afghanistan's economy in crisis after Taliban take-over
item.description: Even before the Taliban gained control, Afghanistan's economy was fragile.

item.title: Kabul arrivals in the UK: 'The happiest moment of my life'
item.description: UK troops are evacuating British nationals and eligible Afghans. Here are some of their stories.

item.title: Afghanistan: The 'undefeated' Panjshir Valley - an hour from Kabul
item.description: The Panjshir Valley has been a flashpoint in Afghanistan's turbulent history - now it's happening again.

item.title: Afghanistan: 'The pain of watching my country burn from afar'
item.description: Hundreds of Afghan have taken refuge in India but they are worried about their families back home.

item.title: Afghanistan chaos: The British families in limbo
item.description: The stories of Britons stuck in Kabul, families in limbo and Afghans starting new lives in the UK.

item.title: Afghanistan: The Sandhurst sisterhood trying to save Afghans
item.description: Desperate Afghans have been messaging British veterans they used to work with asking for help.

item.title: Bilal Sarwary: 'The plane hit the tower and all our lives changed'
item.description: Afghan journalist Bilal Sarwary was selling carpets when 9/11 happened. From that day on, everything changed.

item.title: Aryana Sayeed: Afghanistan returns to miserable time for women
item.description: Afghan singer Aryana Sayeed on fleeing the country and her concerns for those who remain.

item.title: What is Sharia law? What does it mean for women in Afghanistan?
item.description: The Taliban say they will govern Afghanistan according to Sharia, or Islamic law

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Swimmers Hannah Russell and Reece Dunn land gold
item.description: Hannah Russell and debutant Reece Dunn both win swimming golds for Great Britain at the Tokyo Paralympics.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Who are Great Britain's medal winners?
item.description: A list of the Great Britain medal winners from the Tokyo 2020 Paralympics.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics medal table - which country has won most golds?
item.description: Which country is leading the medal table for the Tokyo 2020 Paralympics? How are Great Britain getting on?

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Stef Reid on Scrabble in prison, lockdown baking & breaking barriers
item.description: Great Britain's Stef Reid tells BBC Sport about playing Scrabble with prison inmates, making the world's best cookies, and her mindset ahead of competing in the Tokyo Paralympics.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: What you need to know about Paralympic classification
item.description: From KL1 to PT2 and F11 to SB6 - everything you need to know about classification at the Paralympic Games.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Sport-by-sport guide
item.description: Twenty-two sports will feature in the Tokyo Paralympics - find out more about them all here.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Lee Pearson wins 12th gold as GB enjoy cycling and swimming success
item.description: Lee Pearson wins his 12th gold medal as Great Britain enjoy a successful day two at the Tokyo Paralympics

item.title: GB's Kearney wins 100m freestyle gold in record time
item.description: Watch ParalympicsGB's Tully Kearney win gold in the women's S5 100m freestyle final in Tokyo, breaking her own world record.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Jaco van Gass - from injury in Afghanistan to Paralympic champion
item.description: Twelve years ago, Jaco van Gass was fighting for his life after being injured in Afghanistan. Now he's a Paralympic champion.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Eight global athletes to watch at Games
item.description: From the Blade Jumper to the dancing star and the Tik Tok influencer, meet some of the global athletes hoping to make an impact at the Tokyo Paralympics.

item.title: Shot in the head in Angola, left for dead, now a Wetherspoons star
item.description: Cesar Kimbirima fled Angola after being shot four times and spending five months in a coma.

item.title: Michael Knighton: The man who could have bought Man Utd for £10m but walked away
item.description: In August 1989, Michael Knighton celebrated his Manchester United takeover deal at Old Trafford. But the plotting against him had just begun.

item.title: India's living dead: 'They stared at me like I was a ghost'
item.description: If you're dead you can't own land - so if someone obtains your death certificate you could lose everything.

item.title: Peter Karlsson: The painful verdict on Swedish ice hockey player's 1995 killing
item.description: Peter Karlsson was stabbed to death in the street. His killer said he was protecting himself - via the so-called 'gay panic' defence.
